title: Are you a toxic player? Join DeTox!
body:
After copping a 14 day ban for losing my marbles at our troll Kayle jungle ("lel cant wait to lose", walks into 5 enemies), I think I'm finally exhausted with having typed screaming matches against bullcrap that is out of my control. 

What I would like to do, is create some kind of group or...community...thing...called DeTox. Something that can encourage behavior reform without the need for crawling out, mangled from underneath a banhammer. Something BY the LoL community, FOR the LoL community. Something where previously toxic asshole players can come forward, speak with groups of similar players, and talk about better things to do.

I'm not sure how to structure it though. 

Anyone wanna help with this?

replies.body: Sounds like a great idea, would love to hear about how it goes! Feel free to reach out if there is anything I could do to help

Thanks man!

The problem is, I lack the technical know-how and spare time to manage a website (which would ideally be the best option, as LoL forums and Facebook would make people who are trying to reform too easy a target for antagonisers), and the couple of friends I have who ARE savvy enough to build a website lack the interest in the game itself to make it worth their while. 

So basically, I have a good IDEA on what I want to do (a place where players who are predisposed to anger can safely vent, calm down and ultimately laugh and improve themselves without spilling out their bile in-game), but I haven't the tools or experience to put it into practice. 

I'm just a highly emotional player trying his best to improve his garbage in-game attitude, it's frankly a miracle I can turn my computer ON, let alone make something cool with it. In all likelihood I'll just palm the idea of to someone with the resources to manage it. Whether it becomes a dinky little website in a dusty corner of the internet that a few dozen people visit once in a while, or a glossy new tentacle sprouting from the pulsating mass that is the ever growing Riot Games, is irrelevant to me. I just want to be helpful is some way.

So for now, ideas shall continue to be kicked around.

Thoughts on creating a closed/private facebook group? It has moderation tools so you can keep the group positive and remove people who are just there to troll.

There are many successful LoL facebook groups already like;

[League of Legends NZ](https://www.facebook.com/groups/lolnz/)
[Summoners Society](https://www.facebook.com/groups/SummonersSocietyOCE/)
[QLD League of Legends](https://www.facebook.com/groups/LeagueofLegendsQLD)
[League of Legends Bootcamp](https://www.facebook.com/groups/LoLBootcamp/)

I would like to help.

I'm what you'd call a positive player. Always try my hardest, never get emotional in game, and I don't play teemo. :P

I even wrote an article last year about how you can improve your play with positivity; http://duoqueue.net.au/how-you-can-improve-your-play-with-positivity/

I'd be happy to get on board if this becomes a thing :)

I'm positive too and happy to help. 
Tho I do have playstyles that rub people up the wrong way, like Teemo, top Vlad, Fizz and being good at grabs.
But I'm always the voice of reason and normally bad puns.

PS Jason, nice guide :)
> [{quoted}](name=Infected Walnut,realm=OCE,application-id=Ntey9fRZ,discussion-id=9Zqoy8fh,comment-id=0003,timestamp=2015-08-17T01:00:35.134+0000)
>
> It would have to be some place safe, where people could choose to post either anonymously or with an ID, because if they posted with their in game names I could see people adding them and them flaming them for their behaviour.

That's the thing too, I play PD2 and the forums are a bit of a witch-hunt when it comes to cheaters and I expect the same thing would happen to some ex-toxic players. The challenge is making this work without it becoming overrun by trolls and spammers.
But if other people are the cause of your problems why should you apologise for being angry?

See that's the thing. I wouldn't ever expect anyone to apologize for venting, it's just that in-game is the wrong place to do it. 

Think of your average League of Legends game as a dinner table. You've got ten people sitting at it, and they are all scrambling and cutting and slurping and snarfing down delicious turkey. During this meal (game match) there is occasionally gonna be some unpleasant drooling onto the fancy tablecloth by an unruly attendant. It might not be that bad, hell it might not even really be their fault...they may have been provoked or tricked or whatever...and now their filthy unwanted runoff and half chewed steak gristle (game abuse) is all over the table that everyone is trying to enjoy their meal on. 

Now if there were a garbage bin right next to the table to safely DISCARD all this unwanted junk in, the dinner would continue on much more smoothly. That is what I think League sorely lacks, a garbage bin for garbage attitude, because right now, it's got nowhere to go but all over the table.

Thing is the "other people" are seeking a response, if you give them what they want of course they are going to continue. By ignoring and refusing to acknowledge the actions of a "troll" you're refusing them the thing that keeps them going. If a significant enough amount of people stop "feeding the trolls" they may start to lose interest in our community and actually leave. I'm not saying you shouldn't report the trouble makers but responding to their actions in-game just makes the situation worse.

Maybe a simple Facebook page would be the way to go. People would be posting as themselves, but not as their LoL usernames. That might be a good way to strengthen camaraderie without tossing actual usernames up into the air to be abused.

A better option would be a website dedicated to this kind of thing, though there are a few problems with that. The way I see it, it would be better if people had the option to join entirely anonymously (not having to reveal their LoL username or real life details, but still have the option to do so), be able to post in a forums/boards style environment describing their situation and get advice from other people on how they can become more positive (effectively changing their attitude). The problem with that, though, is you would need a few dedicated people to monitor, moderate and maintain the website as well as someone willing to make it (I have a friend who ***might*** be willing to help). Personally I think using Facebook would be a worse idea than using the LoL boards (for example), simply because it's revealing the identities of who people are in real life (even if they make no mention of their LoL username[s]).

Agreed, but unfortunately its a frigging miracle I can even turn my computer ON, let alone build and manage a website. I have friends who are savvy enough with websites to build one. Hell, my old workmate is doing it for a living now, but they lack the interest in the game itself to make it worth their time, and I lack the spare time and know-how to keep it relevant and chugging along. 

I WANT to do something cool but just dunno how yet.
can i help people reform by going kill lane bot with j4 and someone else. because breaking the meta i think really helps people get less toxic (in my opinion)
I think it's a good idea.

It would have to be some place safe, where people could choose to post either anonymously or with an ID, because if they posted with their in game names I could see people adding them and them flaming them for their behaviour.
